issue.title: Add support for tree-shaking
issue.body:
This is an improvement request.
With good practices on exporting the functionalities from a module you can make it possible for bundler to do tree-shaking and remove unused logic from the final website bundle.
It seems to not be possible with Lottie right now, so it bundles the whole library and that can make the website way heavier. Websites are being penalized on their SEO score and user experience because of this.

Any plans to improve this?

comment.body: Dynamic import for your JSONs isn’t an option? Ship them side by side with your built JS and just dynamically import as you need them and let the client-side bundler handle resolution and packaging

issue.title: Parsing error on `[h]:m` string
issue.body: First a huge thanks for providing this library. It has made using markdown in react a breeze. 👍 Recently we discovered an issue with one of our users posting a cell formating string for Excel: `[h]:mm;@` (Yes, I know that things like this should be wrapped inside a code block, but regular users just don't do that) We were using a slighly outdated version (`7.1.5`) that threw an error in the console: `React.cloneElement(...): The argument must be a React element, but you passed null.` We were able to reprodice the problem locally. When passing `[h]:m` to the `` component, it fails to parse the string. Noticing that we were not on the latest version (`7.1.7` as of writing this) we immediately updated to the latest version, which "fixed" the issue, **but `[h]:m` still cannot be parsed, it is now simply omitted from the output.** ### Example Input: `hello [h]:m **world**` Output: `hello world` Expected output: `hello [h]:m world` Here is a sandbox with a reproduction: https://codesandbox.io/s/dark-rgb-fonbki I was expecting to just get the plain text returned when the word is not any kind of markdown syntax. Am I missing something? Is `[h]:m` matching some markdown syntax that I am not familiar with?

comment.body: Fixed in 7.1.8

When passing `[h]:m` to the `` component, it fails to parse the string. Noticing that we were not on the latest version (`7.1.7` as of writing this) we immediately updated to the latest version, which "fixed" the issue, **but `[h]:m` still cannot be parsed, it is now simply omitted from the output.** ### Example Input: `hello [h]:m **world**` Output: `hello world` Expected output: `hello [h]:m world` Here is a sandbox with a reproduction: https://codesandbox.io/s/dark-rgb-fonbki I was expecting to just get the plain text returned when the word is not any kind of markdown syntax. comment.body:
In this case the code in question is being identified as a _reference_, per the [markdown spec](https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax): 

> Then, anywhere in the document, you define your link label > > like this, on a line by itself:
>
> ```
> [id]: http://example.com/  "Optional Title Here"
> ```

issue.title: [Bug] Using as prop on styled function component does not correctly inherit all styles
issue.body:
## Environment ``` "@types/styled-components": "5.1.26", "react": "18.0.0", "react-dom": "18.0.0", "react-scripts": "4.0.3", "styled-components": "5.3.5" ``` I have created a reproduction of the bug in codesandbox here: https://codesandbox.io/s/styled-components-inheritance-bug-mlpyjr?file=/src/App.tsx ## Reproduction ```typescript import "./styles.css"; import styled, { css } from "styled-components"; import { FC, ReactNode } from "react"; // Base button const ButtonInline = styled.button` display: block; padding: 0; background: none; border: none; white-space: no-wrap; background: blue; color: white; `; interface IconButtonProps { icon?: ReactNode; } const IconButton: FC = (props) => { const { icon, children, ...rest } = props; return ( {icon &&
{icon}
} {children} ); }; const StyledIconButton = styled(IconButton)` padding: 4px; margin: 4px 0; ${(props) => props.icon && css` display: flex; align-items: center; `} `; const PrimaryIconButton = styled(StyledIconButton)` // ... other styles `; export default function App() { return (

All buttons should have blue background and white color

ButtonInline StyledIconButton PrimaryIconButton StyledIconButton

But when passing{" "} as {" "} property styles are ommited

PrimaryIconButton Link
); } ``` ## Expected Behavior Components should inherit styles in their hirachy or there should be a warning about this behaviour in the docs. ## Actual Behavior When using `as="a"` on `PrimaryIconButton` the implementation of `StyledIconButton` is not implemented and therefore styles from `ButtonInline` are ommited. If `as` is ommited everything works fine like in the example.

issue.title: The tag <text> is unrecognized in this browser
issue.body:
<!-- BUG TEMPLATE -->
## Environment
```

## System:
 - OS: macOS 12.3
 - CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
 - Memory: 114.47 MB / 16.00 GB
 - Shell: 5.8 - /bin/zsh
## Binaries:
 - Node: 19.0.1 - /opt/homebrew/bin/node
 - Yarn: 1.22.19 - /opt/homebrew/bin/yarn
 - npm: 8.19.2 - /opt/homebrew/bin/npm
 
```

## Reproduction

[Click here to check how to reproduce](https://codesandbox.io/s/styled-components-base-forked-qdrh38)


```

import React from "react";
import styled from 'styled-components';
import { render } from "react-dom";

import Wrapper from "./Wrapper";

export const Txt = styled.text`
  font-family: 'Inter', sans-serif;
  font-style: normal;
  font-weight: 400;
  font-size: 11px;
  line-height: 108.52%;
  margin: auto;
  text-align: center;

  color: #ffffff;
`;

// Render these styled components like normal react components.
// They will pass on all props and work
// like normal react components – except they're styled!
const App = () => (
  <Wrapper>
    <Txt>Hello World, this is my first styled component!</Txt>
  </Wrapper>
);

render(<App />, document.getElementById("root"));


```
## Steps to reproduce

Use styled.text`` created component.

## Expected Behavior

No error on console log related to capital letter.

## Actual Behavior

Browser complains because generated component has no capital letter.

comment.body: We have a list of "known" HTML elements in the library, which form the shortcuts supported in the `styled.{element}` pattern. If there's a new HTML element not on the list, please file a PR to add it. Otherwise you may create a styled-component of any time using the `styled()` wrapper.

issue.title: vulnerability in styled-components@5.3.6
issue.body:
As Snyk accuses there are vulnerabilities in styled-components, would it be possible to fix them?

Affected versions of this package are vulnerable to Undesired Behavior via the postinstall.js file which looks for users using a ru time-zone to show a political protest message using the console.warn() function. Also, the absence of this file in the 5.3.4 version causes a crash when the package is installed.

https://security.snyk.io/package/npm/styled-components/5.3.6

comment.body: The statement was added to v5 after the v6 split so it will naturally fade off with v6 release.

issue.title: Upgrading to React 17 Breaks StyleSheetManager target
issue.body:
## Environment
## Binaries:
 - Node: 12.22.12 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v12.22.12/bin/node
 - npm: 6.14.16 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v12.22.12/bin/npm
## npmPackages:
 - babel-plugin-styled-components: 1.10.7 => 1.10.7 
 - styled-components: ^5.2.1 => 5.3.5 

I'm working with an application hosted inside a shadow-node. This is due to the fact that we're being inserted into Shopify stores. To be able to style inside the shadow-node, we're using StyleSheetManager and targeting a container inside the shadow-dom. We recently upgraded to React17 (from 16) for an unrelated issue, and now the dom element designated as the "target" doesn't get the styles object appended to it. Other than the upgrade to React 17 nothing changed. 
]

comment.body: Any chance you could put together a sandbox with a minimal reproduction of the issue? Haven’t worked with shadow-dom before.

issue.title: className mismatch when the styled function is wrapped inside another one
issue.body:
## Description When wrapping the `styled` function call inside another function like : ```js import styled from "styled-components"; const wrapper = (component) => { return styled(component); }; const BoxSC = styled(`h2`)` text-align: center; `; const BoxWrapper = wrapper(`h2`)` <--- note the use of the wrapper here text-align: center; `; export default function Home() { return (
- This component is fine - - This component triggers a mismatch when modified -
); } ``` there is a "Prop `className` did not match." error in the console after an edit was made to the page. Note that: - I am using Next.js and need SSR capabilities. - Reproduced the bug with NextJS v9, 11, 12, 13. - Reproduced the bug with Style-components v4, 5. - Reproduced the bug with babel, babel-plugin-styled-components (and the `.babelrc` file) and SWC. - Did NOT reproduce the bug when the `styled` function is **not** wrapped but used directly. - I have read https://github.com/vercel/next.js/issues/7322 and tried the solutions mentioned there. - Used [the Nextjs example](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/tree/canary/examples/with-styled-components) and went through the [SC documentation about Next](https://styled-components.com/docs/advanced#nextjs) (I have the custom _document). ## Environment ``` ## System: - OS: macOS 13.0.1 - CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro - Memory: 80.73 MB / 16.00 GB - Shell: 5.8.1 - /bin/zsh ## Binaries: - Node: 16.14.2 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.14.2/bin/node - Yarn: 1.22.18 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.14.2/bin/yarn - npm: 8.6.0 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.14.2/bin/npm - Watchman: 2022.03.21.00 - /opt/homebrew/bin/watchman ## npmPackages: - styled-components: ^5.3.6 => 5.3.6 ``` ## Reproduction [Link to repo](https://github.com/thibautsabot/sc-mismatch) ## Steps to reproduce 1/ clone the repo 2/ npm install 3/ npm run dev 4/ go to http://localhost:3000 5/ make a change in the pages/index.tsx file 6/ refresh the browser Screencast: https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9283289/202420650-bf97a0a5-7a17-459c-a839-290da857fdc2.mp4 ## Expected Behavior Not having any mismatch error

issue.title: Adding axis lock
issue.body:
Fixes #538

`lockedAxis` and `allowedDeviation` properties on `<Draggable />` restricting dragging to one axis but permitting some movement in the blocked axis.

The main counter point was that this library is meant to feel physical so outright blocking movement in one axis feels like you are interacting with software as not many physical things are "on rails". However sometimes you do just need to lock movement to one axis but given some allowed deviation along the blocked axis (for instance 40px deviation allows -40px to +40px along the blocked axis).

There is a slight problem that I've seen on previous external solutions where keyboard controls are forgotten about, locked axis shouldn't be used as an alternative to `type`.

issue.title: Generate more consistent class names between client and server
issue.body: This commit fixes the _"Warning: Prop `className` did not match"_ error emitted during React DOM hydration. The reason for this was the the internal tracker for component identifiers was incremented for every component construction during server-side compilation, but client-side it happened only for the components in the current view, since JS code is typically code-splitted for the browser. The fix is to take a different approach for generating component ids entirely. Instead of only looking at the component's displayName, its parent displayName and the running increment, the actual style rule set is also used for generating the hash part of the id. The running increment is still there but only used for components with exactly the same hash. This happens with identical styles and display names. When this collision happens, the generated class name is incremented with a separate literal counter like `sc-hash`, `sc-hash-1`, ... ---- Here's a fancy screenshot of a React Remix project I tested this on. Remix builds with esbuild so I couldn't use the babel plugin to pre-generate component ids. | Before | After | |:-------|:------| | | |

comment.body:
Let’s put it this way, it’s not a problem we are willing to solve in the library itself due to the performance impacts you mentioned. We’ve had a babel implementation for years to handle this in a performant way, and even SWC has added support by porting our babel plugin to their infrastructure.

Esbuild will need to do the same if it wants to be as relevant as other compilers; many other libraries take a similar approach to adding behaviors/features via compiler plugins. 

SSR is an edge case that we support, React itself hasn’t had proper primitives to support SSR until recently.

Fixed the usage of mdxLoader without passing mdxLoaderOptions. Without this change, MDX headers will not be linked via remark-slug + addon-docs.

payload.description: 📦 Zero-configuration bundler for tiny modules.

pull_request.title: fix: disable tree-shaking via PURE annotations when compression is disabled
pull_request.body:
When building a library, "pure" comments are often added to various bits and pieces to ensure tree-shaking works properly in the destination bundle. Compression via terser will automatically drop these hints in some cases, so disabling compression serves the purpose of leaving total minification up to the destination bundler.

At the moment, `rollup` takes these pure comments into account as well when bundling which can lead to early-dropping of statements that are meant to be dropped _later_ in the destination bundler. We should disable "pure" comment-related treeshaking in microbundle when compression is turned off to ensure this use case works as expected.

For example, here's a use case which involves setting `displayName` on a component in a way that if the component is tree-shaken, the displayName goes away as well:

```tsx
const Foo = (props) => <div {...props} />

/*#​__PURE__*/Object.assign(Foo, { displayName: 'Foo' });
```

issue.title: styled-components v6

labels.description: proposals for the next major of styled-components

issue.body:
> **What is this?** This is a list of discussions and questions that need answering before we start a v6 complete rewrite and effort. This is for our own notes and transparency but for now I'll **lock** this issue for a week until we answer some of these questions myself, after which this issue will be **unlocked** and open for discussion and other members of the CSS-in-JS community that we'll talk to to add their notes and opinions.
> So this issue isn't yet (or at all) for general discussion or consumption and is just reflecting our thought process for the time being. More umbrella issues will follow.

### What happens to `@font-face`?

**Context:** There's a Chrome quirk that reloads fonts and images on each change to the `CSSStyleSheet` (which is definitely unintended) which can cause a flash of fonts when no cache header has been added. It's also possible that this is already fixed in newer versions. _Investigation needed._

Nothing, special behaviour could still remain dropped, although it's possible we could have a workaround that directly mutates the inserted `@font-face` at-rule to swap out the URL with something else in development to make this issue less apparent.

### What happens to `@import`?

Nothing, special behaviour could still remain dropped, although a warning would be welcome.

### Do we support IE11 in v6?

It'd be great to drop IE11 and this may just now be possible since people could stop upgrading when they need IE11 support since v4/v5 have been relatively stable (as long as we still patch bugs)

### Do we start with a rewrite?

**Current Answer:** A TypeScript rewrite would be welcome. We can still auto-generate typings for Flow and Flow in general is "falling out of popularity." Meanwhile a TypeScript rewrite is just ergonomically nicer for ourselves.

Currently we believe that a rewrite to get rid of old legacy code paths and questionable implementation details is the way forward.

### What happens to the style system?

We can split out our style management system into a separate non-React subpackage that is usable by other libraries so that other style systems can better cooperate with styled-components.

### Is our specificity approach ripe for an upgrade?

In the current systems we have an elaborate system that ensures that style ordering is predictable and solid because of composition. This is _really important_, but hinders optimisations for static styles. It's possible that we may be able to come up with more or better solutions for this. _Investigation needed._

### What about atomic rules?

In theory atomic rules in production could help with a lot of optimisations. However that means we'll have to ensure that it runs identically to a non-atomic system in terms of specificity and ordering.

Targeting other components or using `+ &` would also still need component IDs, so _Investigation needed._

### What about bundle size?

Just by getting rid of the `TextNode` fallback / alternative and using `Proxy` for the styled aliases we'd get rid of a large chunk of complexity.

In theory the `$` prefix, i.e. `$variant` syntax would get rid of prop filtering too.

### Do we utilise new approaches around CSS Custom Properties?

With the above we should also put this up for a question. If we split styling up into static and dynamic parts we could even split that static parts into value changes that can be expressed with custom properties.

That being said, if we do want to do this, our specificity and ordering approach _will break!_

### What about our theming system?

Even in a TypeScript rewrite this will be an issue as no type can be spread out via the `ThemeProvider`. So either we need a factory here or another system that distributes the theme type better. _Investigation needed._

### What about ENV-based switches?

Apart from `NODE_ENV: 'production' | 'development'` no switch should be required. We moved to SSR having its own `StyleSheetManager` and it's highly likely that no other switch will be needed to prefer client v server logic anymore. So no `typeof` checks on globals should be performed in v6.

**This list is still incomplete**

comment.body: That being said, we are using useInsertionEffect for cGS where available

issue.title: Class added through DOM API gets removed when a styled-component prop changes
issue.body:
This is a bug report.

## Environment
This bug is not related to an environment. Anyway, here's mine:
```## System:
 - OS: macOS 12.6
 - CPU: (8) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
 - Memory: 93.45 MB / 16.00 GB
 - Shell: 3.2.57 - /bin/bash
## Binaries:
 - Node: 16.14.2 - /usr/local/bin/node
 - Yarn: 1.22.19 - /opt/homebrew/bin/yarn
 - npm: 8.19.0 - ~/projects/shopify-store-theme/shopify-react/node_modules/.bin/npm
 - Watchman: 2022.09.05.00 - /opt/homebrew/bin/watchman
## npmPackages:
 - babel-plugin-styled-components: ^2.0.7 => 2.0.7 
 - styled-components: ^5.3.5 => 5.3.5 
```

## Reproduction
This is an interactive codesandbox, you can find steps inside the Codesandbox and down below

https://codesandbox.io/s/priceless-liskov-ofhzb7?file=/src/App.js

## Steps to reproduce
1. Add a class to any styled-component using the DOM API (`classList.add` for example)
2. Change a prop of the same styled-component
3. The class added in step one disappears

## Expected Behavior
Class added in step 1 should persist

## Actual Behavior
Class gets removed from the DOM element

I could not find any similar issue. 

My real-case scenario is a styled-component `img` tag using [lazysizes](https://github.com/aFarkas/lazysizes) with `lqip`. `lazysizes` adds a `.ls-is-cached` that is useful to avoid repeating the blur effect every time the image is shown on the screen. But since the `img` is a styled-component and `display` none/block is controlled through a prop, the `.ls-is-cached` class gets removed and the blur effect is show again and again

comment.body: This is a general React issue, not specific to styled-components. When you use libraries that modify the DOM outside of React, you always risk those changes being overwritten as React re-renders and detects an HTML attribute discrepancy. The  solution is to write some sort of adapter code so React is injecting the class itself.

release.name: v6.0.0-beta.6
release.body:
```
yarn add styled-components@beta
```

## What's Changed

* Bump stylis to version 4.1.3 by @lunaris in https://github.com/styled-components/styled-components/pull/3860 (adds `@container` CSS  support)
* Fix various type issues

## Breaking changes in v6 (as of this version)

* now using `stylis` v4 (if using `stylis-plugin-rtl` you'll need to upgrade to the newer version)
* dropped `$as` and `$forwardedAs` props (use `as` or `forwardedAs`)
* dropped automatic prop filtering, use transient props (`$` prefix) for stuff you don't want to be passed to child component / HTML
* node >= 14 needed

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/styled-components/styled-components/compare/v6.0.0-beta.5...v6.0.0-beta.6

pull_request.title: fix: (React Native) passing testID as attrs property
pull_request.body:
PR that broke down the logic: https://github.com/styled-components/styled-components/pull/3365/files

Currently, adding testID as an attribute in `attrs` does not work, because testID is always overwritten with regular prop as `undefined`.

This change adds the ability to specify testID with `.attrs()`, as was possible before version 5.2.2

```
const MyComponent = styled.View.attrs({ testID: 'something' })`` // such code does not work
```

forkee.description: Babel plugin to generate React components' displayName

issue.title: [FR] add "pure" comment so appended displayName do not break tree-shaking
issue.body:
The way most minification tree-shaking checkers work is to determine if code is side-effectful, and then if not if it is in use. The act of adding `displayName` to exported components currently is an assignment to the component which trips the "side effect" detector.

We can circumvent this by adding a [pure annotation comment](https://github.com/styled-components/babel-plugin-styled-components/blob/a7d839465ec4cdf815ea8bc0b0e4bb2f3ffda5a1/src/visitors/pure.js#L7). The end result is `displayName` is retained as long as the component is physically used somewhere, but tree-shaken if not.

issue.title: [FR] Ability to set a prefix for generated display names
issue.body:
I could see this plugin as being very useful for libraries :)

For example, our company design system recommends usage like:

```tsx
import * as DS from '@company/ds'

<DS.Button />
```

It would be cool to be able to supply the "DS." prefix to the generated display name so devtools more closely matches code :)

issue.title: Add support for tree-shaking
issue.body:
This is an improvement request.
With good practices on exporting the functionalities from a module you can make it possible for bundler to do tree-shaking and remove unused logic from the final website bundle.
It seems to not be possible with Lottie right now, so it bundles the whole library and that can make the website way heavier. Websites are being penalized on their SEO score and user experience because of this.

Any plans to improve this?

issue.title: Parsing error on `[h]:m` string
issue.body: First a huge thanks for providing this library. It has made using markdown in react a breeze. 👍 Recently we discovered an issue with one of our users posting a cell formating string for Excel: `[h]:mm;@` (Yes, I know that things like this should be wrapped inside a code block, but regular users just don't do that) We were using a slighly outdated version (`7.1.5`) that threw an error in the console: `React.cloneElement(...): The argument must be a React element, but you passed null.` We were able to reprodice the problem locally. When passing `[h]:m` to the `` component, it fails to parse the string. Noticing that we were not on the latest version (`7.1.7` as of writing this) we immediately updated to the latest version, which "fixed" the issue, **but `[h]:m` still cannot be parsed, it is now simply omitted from the output.** ### Example Input: `hello [h]:m **world**` Output: `hello world` Expected output: `hello [h]:m world` Here is a sandbox with a reproduction: https://codesandbox.io/s/dark-rgb-fonbki I was expecting to just get the plain text returned when the word is not any kind of markdown syntax. Am I missing something? Is `[h]:m` matching some markdown syntax that I am not familiar with?

comment.body: Fixed in 7.1.8

comment.body:
In this case the code in question is being identified as a _reference_, per the [markdown spec](https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax): 

> Then, anywhere in the document, you define your link label > > like this, on a line by itself:
>
> ```
> [id]: http://example.com/  "Optional Title Here"
> ```

When passing `[h]:m` to the `` component, it fails to parse the string. Noticing that we were not on the latest version (`7.1.7` as of writing this) we immediately updated to the latest version, which "fixed" the issue, **but `[h]:m` still cannot be parsed, it is now simply omitted from the output.** ### Example Input: `hello [h]:m **world**` Output: `hello world` Expected output: `hello [h]:m world` Here is a sandbox with a reproduction: https://codesandbox.io/s/dark-rgb-fonbki I was expecting to just get the plain text returned when the word is not any kind of markdown syntax. Am I missing something? Is `[h]:m` matching some markdown syntax that I am not familiar with?

comment.body: Will take a look

issue.title: [Bug] Using as prop on styled function component does not correctly inherit all styles
issue.body:
## Environment ``` "@types/styled-components": "5.1.26", "react": "18.0.0", "react-dom": "18.0.0", "react-scripts": "4.0.3", "styled-components": "5.3.5" ``` I have created a reproduction of the bug in codesandbox here: https://codesandbox.io/s/styled-components-inheritance-bug-mlpyjr?file=/src/App.tsx ## Reproduction ```typescript import "./styles.css"; import styled, { css } from "styled-components"; import { FC, ReactNode } from "react"; // Base button const ButtonInline = styled.button` display: block; padding: 0; background: none; border: none; white-space: no-wrap; background: blue; color: white; `; interface IconButtonProps { icon?: ReactNode; } const IconButton: FC = (props) => { const { icon, children, ...rest } = props; return ( {icon &&
{icon}
} {children} ); }; const StyledIconButton = styled(IconButton)` padding: 4px; margin: 4px 0; ${(props) => props.icon && css` display: flex; align-items: center; `} `; const PrimaryIconButton = styled(StyledIconButton)` // ... other styles `; export default function App() { return (

All buttons should have blue background and white color

ButtonInline StyledIconButton PrimaryIconButton StyledIconButton

But when passing{" "} as {" "} property styles are ommited

PrimaryIconButton Link
); } ``` ## Expected Behavior Components should inherit styles in their hirachy or there should be a warning about this behaviour in the docs. ## Actual Behavior When using `as="a"` on `PrimaryIconButton` the implementation of `StyledIconButton` is not implemented and therefore styles from `ButtonInline` are ommited. If `as` is ommited everything works fine like in the example.

issue.title: The tag <text> is unrecognized in this browser
issue.body:
<!-- BUG TEMPLATE -->
## Environment
```

## System:
 - OS: macOS 12.3
 - CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
 - Memory: 114.47 MB / 16.00 GB
 - Shell: 5.8 - /bin/zsh
## Binaries:
 - Node: 19.0.1 - /opt/homebrew/bin/node
 - Yarn: 1.22.19 - /opt/homebrew/bin/yarn
 - npm: 8.19.2 - /opt/homebrew/bin/npm
 
```

## Reproduction

[Click here to check how to reproduce](https://codesandbox.io/s/styled-components-base-forked-qdrh38)


```

import React from "react";
import styled from 'styled-components';
import { render } from "react-dom";

import Wrapper from "./Wrapper";

export const Txt = styled.text`
  font-family: 'Inter', sans-serif;
  font-style: normal;
  font-weight: 400;
  font-size: 11px;
  line-height: 108.52%;
  margin: auto;
  text-align: center;

  color: #ffffff;
`;

// Render these styled components like normal react components.
// They will pass on all props and work
// like normal react components – except they're styled!
const App = () => (
  <Wrapper>
    <Txt>Hello World, this is my first styled component!</Txt>
  </Wrapper>
);

render(<App />, document.getElementById("root"));


```
## Steps to reproduce

Use styled.text`` created component.

## Expected Behavior

No error on console log related to capital letter.

## Actual Behavior

Browser complains because generated component has no capital letter.

comment.body: We have a list of "known" HTML elements in the library, which form the shortcuts supported in the `styled.{element}` pattern. If there's a new HTML element not on the list, please file a PR to add it. Otherwise you may create a styled-component of any time using the `styled()` wrapper.

issue.title: vulnerability in styled-components@5.3.6
issue.body:
As Snyk accuses there are vulnerabilities in styled-components, would it be possible to fix them?

Affected versions of this package are vulnerable to Undesired Behavior via the postinstall.js file which looks for users using a ru time-zone to show a political protest message using the console.warn() function. Also, the absence of this file in the 5.3.4 version causes a crash when the package is installed.

https://security.snyk.io/package/npm/styled-components/5.3.6

comment.body: The statement was added to v5 after the v6 split so it will naturally fade off with v6 release.

issue.title: Upgrading to React 17 Breaks StyleSheetManager target
issue.body:
## Environment
## Binaries:
 - Node: 12.22.12 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v12.22.12/bin/node
 - npm: 6.14.16 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v12.22.12/bin/npm
## npmPackages:
 - babel-plugin-styled-components: 1.10.7 => 1.10.7 
 - styled-components: ^5.2.1 => 5.3.5 

I'm working with an application hosted inside a shadow-node. This is due to the fact that we're being inserted into Shopify stores. To be able to style inside the shadow-node, we're using StyleSheetManager and targeting a container inside the shadow-dom. We recently upgraded to React17 (from 16) for an unrelated issue, and now the dom element designated as the "target" doesn't get the styles object appended to it. Other than the upgrade to React 17 nothing changed. 
]

issue.title: className mismatch when the styled function is wrapped inside another one
issue.body:
## Description When wrapping the `styled` function call inside another function like : ```js import styled from "styled-components"; const wrapper = (component) => { return styled(component); }; const BoxSC = styled(`h2`)` text-align: center; `; const BoxWrapper = wrapper(`h2`)` <--- note the use of the wrapper here text-align: center; `; export default function Home() { return (
- This component is fine - - This component triggers a mismatch when modified -
); } ``` there is a "Prop `className` did not match." error in the console after an edit was made to the page. Note that: - I am using Next.js and need SSR capabilities. - Reproduced the bug with NextJS v9, 11, 12, 13. - Reproduced the bug with Style-components v4, 5. - Reproduced the bug with babel, babel-plugin-styled-components (and the `.babelrc` file) and SWC. - Did NOT reproduce the bug when the `styled` function is **not** wrapped but used directly. - I have read https://github.com/vercel/next.js/issues/7322 and tried the solutions mentioned there. - Used [the Nextjs example](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/tree/canary/examples/with-styled-components) and went through the [SC documentation about Next](https://styled-components.com/docs/advanced#nextjs) (I have the custom _document). ## Environment ``` ## System: - OS: macOS 13.0.1 - CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro - Memory: 80.73 MB / 16.00 GB - Shell: 5.8.1 - /bin/zsh ## Binaries: - Node: 16.14.2 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.14.2/bin/node - Yarn: 1.22.18 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.14.2/bin/yarn - npm: 8.6.0 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.14.2/bin/npm - Watchman: 2022.03.21.00 - /opt/homebrew/bin/watchman ## npmPackages: - styled-components: ^5.3.6 => 5.3.6 ``` ## Reproduction [Link to repo](https://github.com/thibautsabot/sc-mismatch) ## Steps to reproduce 1/ clone the repo 2/ npm install 3/ npm run dev 4/ go to http://localhost:3000 5/ make a change in the pages/index.tsx file 6/ refresh the browser Screencast: https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9283289/202420650-bf97a0a5-7a17-459c-a839-290da857fdc2.mp4 ## Expected Behavior Not having any mismatch error

comment.body: The babel plugin is not able to annotate the code properly because of the indirection, unfortunately. If you’re up for adding support for this to the babel plugin we’d appreciate it!

issue.title: Adding axis lock
issue.body:
Fixes #538

`lockedAxis` and `allowedDeviation` properties on `<Draggable />` restricting dragging to one axis but permitting some movement in the blocked axis.

The main counter point was that this library is meant to feel physical so outright blocking movement in one axis feels like you are interacting with software as not many physical things are "on rails". However sometimes you do just need to lock movement to one axis but given some allowed deviation along the blocked axis (for instance 40px deviation allows -40px to +40px along the blocked axis).

There is a slight problem that I've seen on previous external solutions where keyboard controls are forgotten about, locked axis shouldn't be used as an alternative to `type`.

comment.body: @danieldelcore would love this feature when you get the time to review

issue.title: Generate more consistent class names between client and server
issue.body: This commit fixes the _"Warning: Prop `className` did not match"_ error emitted during React DOM hydration. The reason for this was the the internal tracker for component identifiers was incremented for every component construction during server-side compilation, but client-side it happened only for the components in the current view, since JS code is typically code-splitted for the browser. The fix is to take a different approach for generating component ids entirely. Instead of only looking at the component's displayName, its parent displayName and the running increment, the actual style rule set is also used for generating the hash part of the id. The running increment is still there but only used for components with exactly the same hash. This happens with identical styles and display names. When this collision happens, the generated class name is incremented with a separate literal counter like `sc-hash`, `sc-hash-1`, ... ---- Here's a fancy screenshot of a React Remix project I tested this on. Remix builds with esbuild so I couldn't use the babel plugin to pre-generate component ids. | Before | After | |:-------|:------| | | |

comment.body:
Let’s put it this way, it’s not a problem we are willing to solve in the library itself due to the performance impacts you mentioned. We’ve had a babel implementation for years to handle this in a performant way, and even SWC has added support by porting our babel plugin to their infrastructure.

Esbuild will need to do the same if it wants to be as relevant as other compilers; many other libraries take a similar approach to adding behaviors/features via compiler plugins. 

SSR is an edge case that we support, React itself hasn’t had proper primitives to support SSR until recently.

payload.description: 📦 Zero-configuration bundler for tiny modules.

pull_request.title: fix: disable tree-shaking via PURE annotations when compression is disabled
pull_request.body:
When building a library, "pure" comments are often added to various bits and pieces to ensure tree-shaking works properly in the destination bundle. Compression via terser will automatically drop these hints in some cases, so disabling compression serves the purpose of leaving total minification up to the destination bundler.

At the moment, `rollup` takes these pure comments into account as well when bundling which can lead to early-dropping of statements that are meant to be dropped _later_ in the destination bundler. We should disable "pure" comment-related treeshaking in microbundle when compression is turned off to ensure this use case works as expected.

For example, here's a use case which involves setting `displayName` on a component in a way that if the component is tree-shaken, the displayName goes away as well:

```tsx
const Foo = (props) => <div {...props} />

/*#​__PURE__*/Object.assign(Foo, { displayName: 'Foo' });
```

issue.title: styled-components v6

labels.description: proposals for the next major of styled-components

issue.body:
> **What is this?** This is a list of discussions and questions that need answering before we start a v6 complete rewrite and effort. This is for our own notes and transparency but for now I'll **lock** this issue for a week until we answer some of these questions myself, after which this issue will be **unlocked** and open for discussion and other members of the CSS-in-JS community that we'll talk to to add their notes and opinions.
> So this issue isn't yet (or at all) for general discussion or consumption and is just reflecting our thought process for the time being. More umbrella issues will follow.

### What happens to `@font-face`?

**Context:** There's a Chrome quirk that reloads fonts and images on each change to the `CSSStyleSheet` (which is definitely unintended) which can cause a flash of fonts when no cache header has been added. It's also possible that this is already fixed in newer versions. _Investigation needed._

Nothing, special behaviour could still remain dropped, although it's possible we could have a workaround that directly mutates the inserted `@font-face` at-rule to swap out the URL with something else in development to make this issue less apparent.

### What happens to `@import`?

Nothing, special behaviour could still remain dropped, although a warning would be welcome.

### Do we support IE11 in v6?

It'd be great to drop IE11 and this may just now be possible since people could stop upgrading when they need IE11 support since v4/v5 have been relatively stable (as long as we still patch bugs)

### Do we start with a rewrite?

**Current Answer:** A TypeScript rewrite would be welcome. We can still auto-generate typings for Flow and Flow in general is "falling out of popularity." Meanwhile a TypeScript rewrite is just ergonomically nicer for ourselves.

Currently we believe that a rewrite to get rid of old legacy code paths and questionable implementation details is the way forward.

### What happens to the style system?

We can split out our style management system into a separate non-React subpackage that is usable by other libraries so that other style systems can better cooperate with styled-components.

### Is our specificity approach ripe for an upgrade?

In the current systems we have an elaborate system that ensures that style ordering is predictable and solid because of composition. This is _really important_, but hinders optimisations for static styles. It's possible that we may be able to come up with more or better solutions for this. _Investigation needed._

### What about atomic rules?

In theory atomic rules in production could help with a lot of optimisations. However that means we'll have to ensure that it runs identically to a non-atomic system in terms of specificity and ordering.

Targeting other components or using `+ &` would also still need component IDs, so _Investigation needed._

### What about bundle size?

Just by getting rid of the `TextNode` fallback / alternative and using `Proxy` for the styled aliases we'd get rid of a large chunk of complexity.

In theory the `$` prefix, i.e. `$variant` syntax would get rid of prop filtering too.

### Do we utilise new approaches around CSS Custom Properties?

With the above we should also put this up for a question. If we split styling up into static and dynamic parts we could even split that static parts into value changes that can be expressed with custom properties.

That being said, if we do want to do this, our specificity and ordering approach _will break!_

### What about our theming system?

Even in a TypeScript rewrite this will be an issue as no type can be spread out via the `ThemeProvider`. So either we need a factory here or another system that distributes the theme type better. _Investigation needed._

### What about ENV-based switches?

Apart from `NODE_ENV: 'production' | 'development'` no switch should be required. We moved to SSR having its own `StyleSheetManager` and it's highly likely that no other switch will be needed to prefer client v server logic anymore. So no `typeof` checks on globals should be performed in v6.

**This list is still incomplete**

comment.body: That being said, we are using useInsertionEffect for cGS where available

issue.title: Class added through DOM API gets removed when a styled-component prop changes
issue.body:
This is a bug report.

## Environment
This bug is not related to an environment. Anyway, here's mine:
```## System:
 - OS: macOS 12.6
 - CPU: (8) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
 - Memory: 93.45 MB / 16.00 GB
 - Shell: 3.2.57 - /bin/bash
## Binaries:
 - Node: 16.14.2 - /usr/local/bin/node
 - Yarn: 1.22.19 - /opt/homebrew/bin/yarn
 - npm: 8.19.0 - ~/projects/shopify-store-theme/shopify-react/node_modules/.bin/npm
 - Watchman: 2022.09.05.00 - /opt/homebrew/bin/watchman
## npmPackages:
 - babel-plugin-styled-components: ^2.0.7 => 2.0.7 
 - styled-components: ^5.3.5 => 5.3.5 
```

## Reproduction
This is an interactive codesandbox, you can find steps inside the Codesandbox and down below

https://codesandbox.io/s/priceless-liskov-ofhzb7?file=/src/App.js

## Steps to reproduce
1. Add a class to any styled-component using the DOM API (`classList.add` for example)
2. Change a prop of the same styled-component
3. The class added in step one disappears

## Expected Behavior
Class added in step 1 should persist

## Actual Behavior
Class gets removed from the DOM element

I could not find any similar issue. 

My real-case scenario is a styled-component `img` tag using [lazysizes](https://github.com/aFarkas/lazysizes) with `lqip`. `lazysizes` adds a `.ls-is-cached` that is useful to avoid repeating the blur effect every time the image is shown on the screen. But since the `img` is a styled-component and `display` none/block is controlled through a prop, the `.ls-is-cached` class gets removed and the blur effect is show again and again

```

## Reproduction
This is an interactive codesandbox, you can find steps inside the Codesandbox and down below

https://codesandbox.io/s/priceless-liskov-ofhzb7?file=/src/App.js

## Steps to reproduce
1. Add a class to any styled-component using the DOM API (`classList.add` for example)
2. Change a prop of the same styled-component
3. The class added in step one disappears

## Expected Behavior
Class added in step 1 should persist

## Actual Behavior
Class gets removed from the DOM element

I could not find any similar issue. 

My real-case scenario is a styled-component `img` tag using [lazysizes](https://github.com/aFarkas/lazysizes) with `lqip`. `lazysizes` adds a `.ls-is-cached` that is useful to avoid repeating the blur effect every time the image is shown on the screen. But since the `img` is a styled-component and `display` none/block is controlled through a prop, the `.ls-is-cached` class gets removed and the blur effect is show again and again

comment.body: This is a general React issue, not specific to styled-components. When you use libraries that modify the DOM outside of React, you always risk those changes being overwritten as React re-renders and detects an HTML attribute discrepancy. The  solution is to write some sort of adapter code so React is injecting the class itself.

release.name: v6.0.0-beta.6
release.body:
```
yarn add styled-components@beta
```

## What's Changed

* Bump stylis to version 4.1.3 by @lunaris in https://github.com/styled-components/styled-components/pull/3860 (adds `@container` CSS  support)
* Fix various type issues

## Breaking changes in v6 (as of this version)

* now using `stylis` v4 (if using `stylis-plugin-rtl` you'll need to upgrade to the newer version)
* dropped `$as` and `$forwardedAs` props (use `as` or `forwardedAs`)
* dropped automatic prop filtering, use transient props (`$` prefix) for stuff you don't want to be passed to child component / HTML
* node >= 14 needed

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/styled-components/styled-components/compare/v6.0.0-beta.5...v6.0.0-beta.6

pull_request.title: fix: (React Native) passing testID as attrs property
pull_request.body:
PR that broke down the logic: https://github.com/styled-components/styled-components/pull/3365/files

Currently, adding testID as an attribute in `attrs` does not work, because testID is always overwritten with regular prop as `undefined`.

This change adds the ability to specify testID with `.attrs()`, as was possible before version 5.2.2

```
const MyComponent = styled.View.attrs({ testID: 'something' })`` // such code does not work
```

tiny pure helper function call, tree-shaking is properly preserved.

forkee.description: Babel plugin to generate React components' displayName

issue.title: [FR] add "pure" comment so appended displayName do not break tree-shaking
issue.body:
The way most minification tree-shaking checkers work is to determine if code is side-effectful, and then if not if it is in use. The act of adding `displayName` to exported components currently is an assignment to the component which trips the "side effect" detector.

We can circumvent this by adding a [pure annotation comment](https://github.com/styled-components/babel-plugin-styled-components/blob/a7d839465ec4cdf815ea8bc0b0e4bb2f3ffda5a1/src/visitors/pure.js#L7). The end result is `displayName` is retained as long as the component is physically used somewhere, but tree-shaken if not.

issue.title: [FR] Ability to set a prefix for generated display names
issue.body:
I could see this plugin as being very useful for libraries :)

For example, our company design system recommends usage like:

```tsx
import * as DS from '@company/ds'

<DS.Button />
```

It would be cool to be able to supply the "DS." prefix to the generated display name so devtools more closely matches code :)

issue.title: Add support for tree-shaking
issue.body:
This is an improvement request.
With good practices on exporting the functionalities from a module you can make it possible for bundler to do tree-shaking and remove unused logic from the final website bundle.
It seems to not be possible with Lottie right now, so it bundles the whole library and that can make the website way heavier. Websites are being penalized on their SEO score and user experience because of this.

Any plans to improve this?

comment.body: Dynamic import for your JSONs isn’t an option? Ship them side by side with your built JS and just dynamically import as you need them and let the client-side bundler handle resolution and packaging

issue.title: Parsing error on `[h]:m` string
issue.body: First a huge thanks for providing this library. It has made using markdown in react a breeze. 👍 Recently we discovered an issue with one of our users posting a cell formating string for Excel: `[h]:mm;@` (Yes, I know that things like this should be wrapped inside a code block, but regular users just don't do that) We were using a slighly outdated version (`7.1.5`) that threw an error in the console: `React.cloneElement(...): The argument must be a React element, but you passed null.` We were able to reprodice the problem locally. When passing `[h]:m` to the `` component, it fails to parse the string. Noticing that we were not on the latest version (`7.1.7` as of writing this) we immediately updated to the latest version, which "fixed" the issue, **but `[h]:m` still cannot be parsed, it is now simply omitted from the output.** ### Example Input: `hello [h]:m **world**` Output: `hello world` Expected output: `hello [h]:m world` Here is a sandbox with a reproduction: https://codesandbox.io/s/dark-rgb-fonbki I was expecting to just get the plain text returned when the word is not any kind of markdown syntax. Am I missing something? Is `[h]:m` matching some markdown syntax that I am not familiar with?

comment.body: Fixed in 7.1.8

comment.body:
In this case the code in question is being identified as a _reference_, per the [markdown spec](https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax): 

> Then, anywhere in the document, you define your link label > > like this, on a line by itself:
>
> ```
> [id]: http://example.com/  "Optional Title Here"
> ```

## Environment ``` "@types/styled-components": "5.1.26", "react": "18.0.0", "react-dom": "18.0.0", "react-scripts": "4.0.3", "styled-components": "5.3.5" ``` I have created a reproduction of the bug in codesandbox here: https://codesandbox.io/s/styled-components-inheritance-bug-mlpyjr?file=/src/App.tsx ## Reproduction ```typescript import "./styles.css"; import styled, { css } from "styled-components"; import { FC, ReactNode } from "react"; // Base button const ButtonInline = styled.button` display: block; padding: 0; background: none; border: none; white-space: no-wrap; background: blue; color: white; `; interface IconButtonProps { icon?: ReactNode; } const IconButton: FC = (props) => { const { icon, children, ...rest } = props; return ( {icon &&
{icon}
} {children} ); }; const StyledIconButton = styled(IconButton)` padding: 4px; margin: 4px 0; ${(props) => props.icon && css` display: flex; align-items: center; `} `; const PrimaryIconButton = styled(StyledIconButton)` // ... other styles `; export default function App() { return (

All buttons should have blue background and white color

ButtonInline StyledIconButton PrimaryIconButton StyledIconButton

But when passing{" "} as {" "} property styles are ommited

PrimaryIconButton Link
); } ``` ## Expected Behavior Components should inherit styles in their hirachy or there should be a warning about this behaviour in the docs. ## Actual Behavior When using `as="a"` on `PrimaryIconButton` the implementation of `StyledIconButton` is not implemented and therefore styles from `ButtonInline` are ommited. issue.body:
<!-- BUG TEMPLATE -->
## Environment
```

## System:
 - OS: macOS 12.3
 - CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
 - Memory: 114.47 MB / 16.00 GB

```

## Reproduction

[Click here to check how to reproduce](https://codesandbox.io/s/styled-components-base-forked-qdrh38)


```

import React from "react";
import styled from 'styled-components';
import { render } from "react-dom";

import Wrapper from "./Wrapper";

export const Txt = styled.text`
  font-family: 'Inter', sans-serif;
  font-style: normal;
  font-weight: 400;
  font-size: 11px;
  line-height: 108.52%;
  margin: auto;
  text-align: center;

  color: #ffffff;
`;

// Render these styled components like normal react components.
// They will pass on all props and work
// like normal react components – except they're styled!
const App = () => (
  <Wrapper>
    <Txt>Hello World, this is my first styled component!</Txt>
  </Wrapper>
);

render(<App />, document.getElementById("root"));


```
## Steps to reproduce

Use styled.text`` created component.

## Expected Behavior

No error on console log related to capital letter.

## Actual Behavior

Browser complains because generated component has no capital letter.

comment.body: We have a list of "known" HTML elements in the library, which form the shortcuts supported in the `styled.{element}` pattern. If there's a new HTML element not on the list, please file a PR to add it. Otherwise you may create a styled-component of any time using the `styled()` wrapper.

issue.title: vulnerability in styled-components@5.3.6
issue.body:
As Snyk accuses there are vulnerabilities in styled-components, would it be possible to fix them?

Affected versions of this package are vulnerable to Undesired Behavior via the postinstall.js file which looks for users using a ru time-zone to show a political protest message using the console.warn() function. Also, the absence of this file in the 5.3.4 version causes a crash when the package is installed.

https://security.snyk.io/package/npm/styled-components/5.3.6

comment.body: The statement was added to v5 after the v6 split so it will naturally fade off with v6 release.

issue.title: Upgrading to React 17 Breaks StyleSheetManager target
issue.body:
## Environment
## Binaries:
 - Node: 12.22.12 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v12.22.12/bin/node
 - npm: 6.14.16 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v12.22.12/bin/npm
## npmPackages:
 - babel-plugin-styled-components: 1.10.7 => 1.10.7 
 - styled-components: ^5.2.1 => 5.3.5 

I'm working with an application hosted inside a shadow-node. This is due to the fact that we're being inserted into Shopify stores. To be able to style inside the shadow-node, we're using StyleSheetManager and targeting a container inside the shadow-dom. We recently upgraded to React17 (from 16) for an unrelated issue, and now the dom element designated as the "target" doesn't get the styles object appended to it. Other than the upgrade to React 17 nothing changed. 
]

comment.body: Any chance you could put together a sandbox with a minimal reproduction of the issue? Haven’t worked with shadow-dom before.

issue.title: className mismatch when the styled function is wrapped inside another one
issue.body:
## Description When wrapping the `styled` function call inside another function like : ```js import styled from "styled-components"; const wrapper = (component) => { return styled(component); }; const BoxSC = styled(`h2`)` text-align: center; `; const BoxWrapper = wrapper(`h2`)` <--- note the use of the wrapper here text-align: center; `; export default function Home() { return (
- This component is fine - - This component triggers a mismatch when modified -
); } ``` there is a "Prop `className` did not match." error in the console after an edit was made to the page. Note that: - I am using Next.js and need SSR capabilities. - Reproduced the bug with NextJS v9, 11, 12, 13. - Reproduced the bug with Style-components v4, 5. - Reproduced the bug with babel, babel-plugin-styled-components (and the `.babelrc` file) and SWC. - Did NOT reproduce the bug when the `styled` function is **not** wrapped but used directly. - I have read https://github.com/vercel/next.js/issues/7322 and tried the solutions mentioned there. - Used [the Nextjs example](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/tree/canary/examples/with-styled-components) and went through the [SC documentation about Next](https://styled-components.com/docs/advanced#nextjs) (I have the custom _document). ## Environment ``` ## System: - OS: macOS 13.0.1 - CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro - Memory: 80.73 MB / 16.00 GB - Shell: 5.8.1 - /bin/zsh ## Binaries: - Node: 16.14.2 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.14.2/bin/node - Yarn: 1.22.18 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.14.2/bin/yarn - npm: 8.6.0 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.14.2/bin/npm - Watchman: 2022.03.21.00 - /opt/homebrew/bin/watchman ## npmPackages: - styled-components: ^5.3.6 => 5.3.6 ``` ## Reproduction [Link to repo](https://github.com/thibautsabot/sc-mismatch) ## Steps to reproduce 1/ clone the repo 2/ npm install 3/ npm run dev 4/ go to http://localhost:3000 5/ make a change in the pages/index.tsx file 6/ refresh the browser Screencast: https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9283289/202420650-bf97a0a5-7a17-459c-a839-290da857fdc2.mp4 ## Expected Behavior Not having any mismatch error

comment.body: The babel plugin is not able to annotate the code properly because of the indirection, unfortunately. If you’re up for adding support for this to the babel plugin we’d appreciate it!

issue.title: Adding axis lock
issue.body:
Fixes #538

`lockedAxis` and `allowedDeviation` properties on `<Draggable />` restricting dragging to one axis but permitting some movement in the blocked axis.

The main counter point was that this library is meant to feel physical so outright blocking movement in one axis feels like you are interacting with software as not many physical things are "on rails". However sometimes you do just need to lock movement to one axis but given some allowed deviation along the blocked axis (for instance 40px deviation allows -40px to +40px along the blocked axis).

There is a slight problem that I've seen on previous external solutions where keyboard controls are forgotten about, locked axis shouldn't be used as an alternative to `type`.

comment.body: @danieldelcore would love this feature when you get the time to review

issue.title: Generate more consistent class names between client and server
issue.body: This commit fixes the _"Warning: Prop `className` did not match"_ error emitted during React DOM hydration. The reason for this was the the internal tracker for component identifiers was incremented for every component construction during server-side compilation, but client-side it happened only for the components in the current view, since JS code is typically code-splitted for the browser. The fix is to take a different approach for generating component ids entirely. Instead of only looking at the component's displayName, its parent displayName and the running increment, the actual style rule set is also used for generating the hash part of the id. The running increment is still there but only used for components with exactly the same hash. This happens with identical styles and display names. When this collision happens, the generated class name is incremented with a separate literal counter like `sc-hash`, `sc-hash-1`, ... ---- Here's a fancy screenshot of a React Remix project I tested this on. Remix builds with esbuild so I couldn't use the babel plugin to pre-generate component ids. | Before | After | |:-------|:------| | | |

comment.body:
Let’s put it this way, it’s not a problem we are willing to solve in the library itself due to the performance impacts you mentioned. We’ve had a babel implementation for years to handle this in a performant way, and even SWC has added support by porting our babel plugin to their infrastructure.

Esbuild will need to do the same if it wants to be as relevant as other compilers; many other libraries take a similar approach to adding behaviors/features via compiler plugins. 

SSR is an edge case that we support, React itself hasn’t had proper primitives to support SSR until recently.

issue.title: Addon-docs: Fix preset to pass MDX loader options properly
issue.body:
This relates to https://github.com/storybookjs/mdx2-csf/pull/12 and https://github.com/storybookjs/mdx2-csf/issues/11.

Issue:

## What I did

Fixed the usage of mdxLoader without passing mdxLoaderOptions. Without this change, MDX headers will not be linked via remark-slug + addon-docs.

I negated the `skipCsf` flag for this use case because in local testing when that was set to true it caused the MDX story to not be loadable (generic error with "CSF not found".)

comment.body: Is this ever going to get fixed? I'm fine if someone takes the work and makes a separate PR but we need to get the markdown plugins working again so things like headline anchor linking work...

payload.description: 📦 Zero-configuration bundler for tiny modules.

pull_request.title: fix: disable tree-shaking via PURE annotations when compression is disabled
pull_request.body:
When building a library, "pure" comments are often added to various bits and pieces to ensure tree-shaking works properly in the destination bundle. Compression via terser will automatically drop these hints in some cases, so disabling compression serves the purpose of leaving total minification up to the destination bundler.

At the moment, `rollup` takes these pure comments into account as well when bundling which can lead to early-dropping of statements that are meant to be dropped _later_ in the destination bundler. We should disable "pure" comment-related treeshaking in microbundle when compression is turned off to ensure this use case works as expected.

For example, here's a use case which involves setting `displayName` on a component in a way that if the component is tree-shaken, the displayName goes away as well:

```tsx
const Foo = (props) => <div {...props} />

/*#​__PURE__*/Object.assign(Foo, { displayName: 'Foo' });
```

issue.body:
> **What is this?** This is a list of discussions and questions that need answering before we start a v6 complete rewrite and effort. This is for our own notes and transparency but for now I'll **lock** this issue for a week until we answer some of these questions myself, after which this issue will be **unlocked** and open for discussion and other members of the CSS-in-JS community that we'll talk to to add their notes and opinions.
> So this issue isn't yet (or at all) for general discussion or consumption and is just reflecting our thought process for the time being. More umbrella issues will follow.

### What happens to `@font-face`?

**Context:** There's a Chrome quirk that reloads fonts and images on each change to the `CSSStyleSheet` (which is definitely unintended) which can cause a flash of fonts when no cache header has been added. It's also possible that this is already fixed in newer versions. _Investigation needed._

Nothing, special behaviour could still remain dropped, although it's possible we could have a workaround that directly mutates the inserted `@font-face` at-rule to swap out the URL with something else in development to make this issue less apparent.

### What happens to `@import`?

Nothing, special behaviour could still remain dropped, although a warning would be welcome.

### Do we support IE11 in v6?

It'd be great to drop IE11 and this may just now be possible since people could stop upgrading when they need IE11 support since v4/v5 have been relatively stable (as long as we still patch bugs)

### Do we start with a rewrite?

**Current Answer:** A TypeScript rewrite would be welcome. We can still auto-generate typings for Flow and Flow in general is "falling out of popularity." Meanwhile a TypeScript rewrite is just ergonomically nicer for ourselves.

Currently we believe that a rewrite to get rid of old legacy code paths and questionable implementation details is the way forward.

### What happens to the style system?

We can split out our style management system into a separate non-React subpackage that is usable by other libraries so that other style systems can better cooperate with styled-components.

### Is our specificity approach ripe for an upgrade?

In the current systems we have an elaborate system that ensures that style ordering is predictable and solid because of composition. This is _really important_, but hinders optimisations for static styles. It's possible that we may be able to come up with more or better solutions for this. _Investigation needed._

### What about atomic rules?

In theory atomic rules in production could help with a lot of optimisations. However that means we'll have to ensure that it runs identically to a non-atomic system in terms of specificity and ordering.

Targeting other components or using `+ &` would also still need component IDs, so _Investigation needed._

### What about bundle size?

Just by getting rid of the `TextNode` fallback / alternative and using `Proxy` for the styled aliases we'd get rid of a large chunk of complexity.

In theory the `$` prefix, i.e. `$variant` syntax would get rid of prop filtering too.

### Do we utilise new approaches around CSS Custom Properties?

With the above we should also put this up for a question. If we split styling up into static and dynamic parts we could even split that static parts into value changes that can be expressed with custom properties.

That being said, if we do want to do this, our specificity and ordering approach _will break!_

### What about our theming system?

Even in a TypeScript rewrite this will be an issue as no type can be spread out via the `ThemeProvider`. So either we need a factory here or another system that distributes the theme type better. _Investigation needed._

### What about ENV-based switches?

Apart from `NODE_ENV: 'production' | 'development'` no switch should be required. We moved to SSR having its own `StyleSheetManager` and it's highly likely that no other switch will be needed to prefer client v server logic anymore. So no `typeof` checks on globals should be performed in v6.

**This list is still incomplete**

comment.body: That being said, we are using useInsertionEffect for cGS where available

issue.title: Class added through DOM API gets removed when a styled-component prop changes
issue.body:
This is a bug report.

## Environment
This bug is not related to an environment. Anyway, here's mine:
```## System:
 - OS: macOS 12.6
 - CPU: (8) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
 - Memory: 93.45 MB / 16.00 GB
 - Shell: 3.2.57 - /bin/bash
## Binaries:
 - Node: 16.14.2 - /usr/local/bin/node
 - Yarn: 1.22.19 - /opt/homebrew/bin/yarn
 - npm: 8.19.0 - ~/projects/shopify-store-theme/shopify-react/node_modules/.bin/npm
 - Watchman: 2022.09.05.00 - /opt/homebrew/bin/watchman
## npmPackages:
 - babel-plugin-styled-components: ^2.0.7 => 2.0.7 
 - styled-components: ^5.3.5 => 5.3.5 
```

## Reproduction
This is an interactive codesandbox, you can find steps inside the Codesandbox and down below

https://codesandbox.io/s/priceless-liskov-ofhzb7?file=/src/App.js

## Steps to reproduce
1. Add a class to any styled-component using the DOM API (`classList.add` for example)
2. Change a prop of the same styled-component
3. The class added in step one disappears

## Expected Behavior
Class added in step 1 should persist

## Actual Behavior
Class gets removed from the DOM element

I could not find any similar issue. 

My real-case scenario is a styled-component `img` tag using [lazysizes](https://github.com/aFarkas/lazysizes) with `lqip`. `lazysizes` adds a `.ls-is-cached` that is useful to avoid repeating the blur effect every time the image is shown on the screen. But since the `img` is a styled-component and `display` none/block is controlled through a prop, the `.ls-is-cached` class gets removed and the blur effect is show again and again

comment.body: This is a general React issue, not specific to styled-components. When you use libraries that modify the DOM outside of React, you always risk those changes being overwritten as React re-renders and detects an HTML attribute discrepancy. The  solution is to write some sort of adapter code so React is injecting the class itself.

issue.title: TypeError: styled.button is not a function
issue.body:
I am building a react ui library with styled-components, I am using rollup to build it. When i use the library with nextJs i get below error 

`TypeError: styled.button is not a function`


This is component i am exporting from the library.
```
export const StyledButton = styled.button`
  background-color: red;
`;
```


## Environment
## System:
 - OS: macOS 12.3
 - CPU: (8) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
 - Memory: 71.52 MB / 16.00 GB
 - Shell: 5.8 - /bin/zsh
## Binaries:
 - Node: 16.18.0 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.18.0/bin/node
 - Yarn: 1.22.19 - /usr/local/bin/yarn
 - npm: 8.19.3 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.18.0/bin/npm
## npmPackages:
 - babel-plugin-styled-components: ^2.0.7 => 2.0.7 
 - styled-components: ^5.3.6 => 5.3.6 


## Steps to reproduce
Import the package in nextJs application, and use the above component.
## Expected Behavior
Component should render button.
## Actual Behavior
Throwing error
`TypeError: styled.button is not a function`

issue.title: styled-components v6 beta feedback
issue.body: Starting a new thread for issues related to `beta` npm tag.

comment.body: Alright beta 6 is out which exposes some more types, updates stylis to theoretically add `@container` CSS support, and includes some type revisions to polymorphic component handling. Hoping we're close to RC now!

release.name: v6.0.0-beta.6
release.body:
```
yarn add styled-components@beta
```

## What's Changed

* Bump stylis to version 4.1.3 by @lunaris in https://github.com/styled-components/styled-components/pull/3860 (adds `@container` CSS  support)
* Fix various type issues

## Breaking changes in v6 (as of this version)

* now using `stylis` v4 (if using `stylis-plugin-rtl` you'll need to upgrade to the newer version)
* dropped `$as` and `$forwardedAs` props (use `as` or `forwardedAs`)
* dropped automatic prop filtering, use transient props (`$` prefix) for stuff you don't want to be passed to child component / HTML
* node >= 14 needed

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/styled-components/styled-components/compare/v6.0.0-beta.5...v6.0.0-beta.6

pull_request.title: fix: (React Native) passing testID as attrs property
pull_request.body:
PR that broke down the logic: https://github.com/styled-components/styled-components/pull/3365/files

Currently, adding testID as an attribute in `attrs` does not work, because testID is always overwritten with regular prop as `undefined`.

This change adds the ability to specify testID with `.attrs()`, as was possible before version 5.2.2

```
const MyComponent = styled.View.attrs({ testID: 'something' })`` // such code does not work
```

refactor: apply displayName via helper fn, fixes tree-shaking

Bundler can't see to properly tree-shake the naked assignment,
even with the PURE comment. By abstracting the assignment into a
tiny pure helper function call, tree-shaking is properly preserved.

payload.description: Babel plugin to generate React components' displayName

forkee.name: babel-plugin-react-displayname
forkee.description: Babel plugin to generate React components' displayName

issue.title: [FR] add "pure" comment so appended displayName do not break tree-shaking
issue.body:
The way most minification tree-shaking checkers work is to determine if code is side-effectful, and then if not if it is in use. The act of adding `displayName` to exported components currently is an assignment to the component which trips the "side effect" detector.

We can circumvent this by adding a [pure annotation comment](https://github.com/styled-components/babel-plugin-styled-components/blob/a7d839465ec4cdf815ea8bc0b0e4bb2f3ffda5a1/src/visitors/pure.js#L7). The end result is `displayName` is retained as long as the component is physically used somewhere, but tree-shaken if not.

issue.title: [FR] Ability to set a prefix for generated display names
issue.body:
I could see this plugin as being very useful for libraries :)

For example, our company design system recommends usage like:

```tsx
import * as DS from '@company/ds'

<DS.Button />
```

It would be cool to be able to supply the "DS." prefix to the generated display name so devtools more closely matches code :)
